DataElement.preferredName: Administered Enteral Tube Feeding Nasogastric Tube Nasojejunal Tube Surgically Placed Gastrostomy Tube Route of Administration Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The indication of whether or not a patient received enteral feeding via nasogastric, nasojejunal or gastrostomy tube.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Administered Enteral Tube Feeding Nasogastric Tube Nasojejunal Tube Surgically Placed Gastrostomy Tube Route of Administration
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test)._Delivery of enteral nutrition via a tube placed into the stomach, duodenum, or jejunum._A tube that is inserted through the nose, down the throat and esophagus, and into the stomach. It can be used to give drugs, liquids, and liquid food, or used to remove substances from the stomach. Giving food through a gastric feeding tube is a type of enteral nutrition._A hollow tube that is directed into the jejunum from the nose._A hollow tube that is inserted into a surgically created external opening into the stomach._Designation of the part of the body through which or into which, or the way in which, the medicinal product is intended to be introduced. In some cases a medicinal product can be intended for more than one route and/or method of administration.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).:Delivery of enteral nutrition via a tube placed into the stomach, duodenum, or jejunum.

Concepts.definition: The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).
Delivery of enteral nutrition via a tube placed into the stomach, duodenum, or jejunum.

Property.preferredName: Nasogastric Tube Nasojejunal Tube Surgically Placed Gastrostomy Tube Route of Administration
Property.preferredDefinition: A tube that is inserted through the nose, down the throat and esophagus, and into the stomach. It can be used to give drugs, liquids, and liquid food, or used to remove substances from the stomach. Giving food through a gastric feeding tube is a type of enteral nutrition.:A hollow tube that is directed into the jejunum from the nose.:A hollow tube that is inserted into a surgically created external opening into the stomach.:Designation of the part of the body through which or into which, or the way in which, the medicinal product is intended to be introduced. In some cases a medicinal product can be intended for more than one route and/or method of administration.

Concepts.definition: A hollow tube that is directed into the stomach from the nose.
A hollow tube that is directed into the jejunum from the nose.
A hollow tube that is inserted into a surgically created external opening into the stomach.

Designation of the part of the body through which or into which, or the way in which, the medicinal product is intended to be introduced. In some cases a medicinal product can be intended for more than one route and/or method of administration.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Any specific activity undertaken during the course of a clinical study or research protocol.

ReferenceDocuments.description: Was the patient administered enteral feeding (EF) via nasogastric (NG), nasojejunal (NJ) or gastrostomy tube (GT)?
